If a person steals a sweater and runs from police in a car, it's not worth 
it to have several vehicles speeding down the highway through traffic over 
a petty theft as there's no cause to believe that person would be a 
physical threat to any1 were they not fleeing from the police; doesn't mean 
you don't try to find them afterwards, it's a risk/benefit analysis.
'Full transparency'? Oversight, public guidelines, you don't have to tell 
everyone every thing that happens to have a system of oversight in place.
I doubt that most people who disagree with the NSA spying program want to 
abolish the police and eliminate the intelligence services entirely, 
hyperbole. The NSA is made up of human beings, they'll use whatever tools 
are at their disposal, of course we should have more oversight than 'I'm 
sure they're not abusing their power, someone has to do it.'; failing that

How do they decide if you're one of these 'listed' people? *By monitoring 
you and analyzing your private and public information*. Is it that you 
don't believe that people communicate things to each other that are legal

might discover illegal activity*.

My brother in law has a contract with NSA, his expertise being computer 
design. Anyways, he told me, the one thing that amazed him about the people 
working and mostly heading up NSA, ONLY communications entering and exiting 
our country are investigated. These people are basically "grossed out" by 
the thought of looking at our citizens personal phone calls, e-mails, and 
text messages. The personal info that is transferred between me and my 
friends is never looked at on its own merit. I supposed if a connection is 
made linking you to problems such as terrorist activity, all bets are off, 
but my friends and I send texts on a certain illegal plant periodically, 
and Marty said feel free. They will never get interested in that stuff. I 
must say, I was happily surprised. And please don't post that he's full of 
shit, he wouldn't lie to me, he brought the topic of his superiors up 
during small talk. ﻿
